III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Bedding and linen
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4138
Section (1) Each resident shall be provided with an individual bed with a
Description clean pillow, mattress and sufficient clean blankets.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth is sleeping outside of their room on the floor.
Investigation On 1/7/25 Complainant reported Youth A was sleeping outside of
his room on the floor. Complainant was contacted by phone on
1/7/25. Complainant indicated Youth A stated he was sleeping on
the floor as punishment.
Interviews:
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on 1/8/25. Chief Administrator reported Youth A briefly slept in the
hallway, due to some youth having COVID and his room being
used to quarantine the sick youth. Follow-up occurred with Chief
Administrator on 1/29/25. Chief Administrator clarified Youth A
was out of the facility, on a pass from 12/24/24 to 12/25/24. Youth
A returned to the facility on 12/26/24. However, all bedrooms were
fully occupied due to needing to use two bedrooms to quarantine
COVID positive youth. Therefore, Youth A slept in the hallway on
a mattress. The quarantine lasted until 1/6/25, at which time,
Youth A was able to move back into his room. Youth A slept in the
middle bed, of three beds in the room. On 1/7/25 Youth A moved
to the bed closest to the door to due to being placed on increased
supervision. The bed closest to the door allowed for better
supervision of Youth A during sleeping hours. Youth A only slept
in the hallway during the COVID quarantine.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/8/25.
Youth A stated he slept on a mattress in the hall for a few nights.
Youth A reported he returned from a family visit and several youth
had COVID. Because of that, Youth A had to sleep on a mattress
in the hallway. Youth A was provided with blankets and pillows for
the nights he was in the hallway. Youth A reported there was
some discussion about sleeping in the hall while on suicide
precautions, but that did not happen.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/8/25.
Therapist reported Youth A was on a pass to visit relatives over
the holidays. However, there was an incident during his visit, and
he returned to the agency earlier than expected. When Youth A
returned, his bedroom was unavailable. Youth A’s bedroom and
another bedroom were being used to quarantine youth that were
positive for COVID. When everyone was healthy again, Youth A
and his belongings returned to his room. Therapist recalled Youth
A was out of his room for approximately nine days. Therapist
noted Youth A was placed on “individual focus” recently due to
2

statements that he wished to kill himself. Because of that, it was
suggested Youth A return to sleeping in the hallway at night so
staff could better supervise him. Therapist stated this was
discussed as Youth A typically slept in the middle bed, of the three
beds in his room. However, it was later decided Youth A would
move to the bed closest to the doorway, not into the hallway.
Nurse was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/8/25. Nurse
reported Youth A returned from a pass and his room was in use
by two youth that tested positive for COVID. More youth became
ill, and the unit ended up using two bedrooms to quarantine the
sick youth. The decision was made to have Youth A sleep on a
mattress in the hallway, as there was not another bed available.
Youth A stated he was “okay” with that decision, but also stated
his rights were being violated.
Tour observation:
Youth A’s bedroom was observed on 1/8/25. Youth A’s mattress
was placed on a frame, in his bedroom, with seasonally
appropriate sheets, blankets and pillows.
Documents reviewed:
COVID-19 Emergency Plan dated 4/1/2020. “If resident
demonstrates positive symptoms of COVID-19, the following will
occur: Resident will be placed in a room by himself, staff will be
assigned to monitor him 1:1 24 hours a day. He will have access
to his own bathroom.”
Consultation
Consultation was provided to the agency regarding their COVID
Emergency Plan. As the plan was completed in 2020 and Center
for Disease Control guidance has evolved, the agency should
update their plan. In addition, the 4/1/2020 plan did not address
additional sleeping areas that would be used in the event rooms
were occupied for quarantine. The updated plan should address
this issue. Lastly, although it did not occur in this situation, there
was discussion about having the youth sleep in the hallway while
on precautions. The agency was reminded this is not permitted.
The action to move the youth to the bed closest to the door for
increased supervision is appropriate and can be used in the
future.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on interviews and
documents reviewed, the agency followed their COVID
Emergency Plan to quarantine youth. While sleeping on a
3

mattress on the floor was not ideal, it was temporary and
necessary to prevent the spread of COVID.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(b) Denial of any essential program service as punishment.
These include, but are not limited to, the following:
(iv) Shelter, clothing, medical care, or essential personal
needs, including culturally specific items.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was denied access to their personal belongings.
Investigation On 1/7/25 Complainant reported Youth A was denied access to
his personal belongings. Complainant was contacted by phone on
1/7/25. Complainant indicated Youth A felt his belongings were
removed as punishment.
Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/8/25.
Youth A reported he was upset about being placed on suicide
precautions. Youth A stated most of his clothing was stored in
totes and locked up. Youth A agreed he was able to access items
with assistance from staff. Youth A stated he had “lots of clothing”
in storage and Nurse would switch items out for him sometimes.
However, he was not able to have all of his items in his bedroom.
Youth A believed he could have his items again if he was off of
safety precautions. Youth A confirmed he had access to hygiene
and other necessary items as needed.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/8/25.
Therapist reported Youth A was known to steal things from peers.
Youth A had accumulated several items that did not belong to him,
as well as items from a visit with relatives. Therefore, the decision
was made to put some of his belongings in storage while ensuring
he had access to necessary items. With fewer items in his room,
staff would be able to determine which belongings were his. Youth
at the facility were typically permitted to have 7 days-worth of
clothing in their room. Youth A had significantly more than that.
4

Youth A had 42 pair of underwear, 16 hoodies, and several pair of
shoes. Many of these items were sent by relatives when Youth A
returned from a recent visit. Staff packed excess into storage
totes, which were kept in a locked area of the facility. Youth A
retained one pair of shoes and seven outfits in his room. Youth A
could access his other belongings to switch out items, with
assistance from staff. In addition, some of Youth A’s other
belongings were put away for safety reasons. Youth A recently
had a pass to visit family, which did not go well. As a result, Youth
A spent some time at a detention facility prior to returning to this
facility. Since his return, Youth A made several self-harm
statements and was therefore placed on suicide precautions. As
Youth A was under increased supervision, some items were not
accessible, such as pencils and other sharp objects. Youth A
expressed to Therapist he was upset about the plan. Shortly after
removing the items, Therapist received an email from Youth A’s
case worker about the allegations and discussed it with Youth A.
Youth A was smiling throughout the discussion, as if he thought it
was funny.
Nurse was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 1/8/25. Nurse
reported Youth A returned from a pass with a significant amount of
clothing. Nurse went through his clothes and pulled out enough
clothing for 7 days, to be stored in his bedroom. All other items
were packed in totes and placed in storage. Nurse provided
photos of all of Youth A’s clothing, to ensure they could account
for all of his belongings in storage. The photos were viewed by
DCWL. Nurse reported she was present with Youth A for a
conversation regarding this allegation. Youth A implied that the
situation was funny and laughed that the facility could be shut
down.
Tour observation:
A walk through of the facility was completed on 1/8/25. Youth A’s
bedroom was viewed. Youth A had a storage tote and shelves for
his personal items. Several outfits consisting of pants, shirts,
sweatshirts, socks, underwear, and shoes were observed.
Documents reviewed:
A current “list of belongings” outlining the items available to Youth
A in his bedroom detailed the following items:
• 5 sweatpants
• 13 pair of socks
• 8 t-shirts
• 1 A-line shirt
• 3 sweatshirts
5

• 6 underwear
• 3 shorts
• 1 pair of crocs
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on interviews and an
inspection at the facility, Youth A was not denied access to
essential personal items.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
